clusters.title: Academic Superiority
clusters.description: Numerous peer-reviewed studies indicate that homeschooled students generally outperform their conventionally schooled counterparts in various domains, including academic achievement, social-emotional development, and success in adulthood. The majority of the research shows positive outcomes for homeschoolers, with a significant percentage of studies reporting better performance in political tolerance, college GPA, and college retention. However, a small fraction of studies found no significant difference or favored conventional schooling.

clusters.title: Testing Success
clusters.description: Homeschooling students consistently outperform their public school counterparts in various standardized tests, with scores typically ranging from 15 to 30 percentile points higher. This educational choice also results in significant financial savings for taxpayers, as families spend considerably less per child on homeschooling than the government does on public school students. Additionally, the academic performance of homeschooled students on tests such as the SAT and ACT surpasses that of public school students, demonstrating the effectiveness of homeschooling methods.

$13,000 per student per year of tax savings for each student not in government-run schooling.
69% of public school eighth-grade students are below proficient in reading.
74% of public school eighth-grade students are below proficient in math.
Homeschool graduates scored 568 in reading, while public school graduates scored 500.
Homeschool graduates scored 525 in math, while public school graduates scored 515.
The average score on the verbal section of the SAT for homeschooled students was 1,093.1.
The average score on the verbal section of the SAT for public school students was 1,012.6.
Homeschooled students scored 80.5 more points on average than public school students on the SAT verbal section.
The average ACT score for all students is around 21 points.
The average ACT score for homeschooling students is generally between 22 and 23 points.
The mean scores in the achievement test of homeschooling students for every subtest are at a minimum of the 80th percentile.
The national mean for standardized tests was the 50th percentile.
Median test scores were in the 65th to 66th percentile range.
Homeschool children outperform public school peers by 15 to 30 percentile points on standardized academic achievement tests.
USA homeschoolers are saving USA taxpayers at least $32 billion during the 2019-2020 public-school year.
Homeschooling represents savings of over $56 billion for taxpayers.

clusters.title: Experience Complexity
clusters.description: The shift to homeschooling during school closures was widespread, with 87% of households engaging in it. While it presented various challenges, including stress for 49% of parents and difficulty keeping children focused, some parents found it rewarding and noted improvements in family closeness and child independence. However, increased technology use and stress levels were also reported, highlighting the complexity of the homeschooling experience.

clusters.title: Enrollment Surge
clusters.description: Homeschooling in the United States has seen significant growth over the years. The number of homeschooled children doubled from 1999 to 2012 and continued to rise, reaching 3.1 million students during the 2021-2022 school year. This reflects a notable increase from 2.5 million in 2019, with the homeschooling population growing at rates between 2% to 8% annually. Approximately 6% to 7% of school-age children are now educated at home, highlighting a shift towards this educational approach.
